metadata.title: Split graphene nano-disks with tunable, multi-band, and high-Q plasmon modes

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Optical Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/optmat
Split graphene nano-disks with tunable, multi-band, and high-Q plasmon modes
Zhengqi Liu∗, Peng Tang, Biao Wu, Leilei Shi, Yuyin Li, Xiaoshan Liu Jiangxi Key Laboratory of Nanomaterials and Sensors, Provincial Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic and Telecommunication, College of Physics and Communication Electronics, Jiangxi Normal University, Nanchang, 330022, Jiangxi, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Graphene plasmonics Plasmonic resonant mode High-Q Quantitative manipulation
A B S T R A C T
We propose a new approach to directly tune spectral Q-factor of the graphene, which has remained challenging in these years. The remarkable tuning of optical properties is reported by splitting graphene disk resonators. In contrast to the single mode of the circular graphene disk, the split graphene nano-disks produce new emerged plasmonic resonant modes, which can be further modified by tuning structural parameters. Such split graphene nano-disks can not only strengthen the multispectral light-graphene interactions drastically but also improve the spectral Q-factor naturally. The spectral Q-factor shows an enhancement of 230–360% for the proposed split graphene nano-disks in comparison with that of the conventional graphene plasmonic mode. With increasing Fermi energy, the tri-band spectrum shows a further narrowing behavior for the resonant bandwidth. A maximal enhancement ∼400% for the spectral Q-factor is obtained. Moreover, the graphene plasmonic properties can be artificially modulated by polarization states of the illumination. This study will open up an avenue for effectively operating graphene photonic devices in the infrared range and pave a way for high-Q multispectral plasmonic graphene structures.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Graphene plasmonics is a new research area that has attracted significant interest owing to the superior electronic and optical properties [1–3]. A variety of different plasmonic structures have been proposed and demonstrated for potential applications in the mid- and far-infrared regions. Graphene is a promising two-dimensional material with resonance energy tunability, sub-wavelength field confinement, relatively long plasmon mode lifetime and other properties, which make graphene an impressive plasmonic material [4–9]. Recently, graphene and its plasmonic behaviors have already shown utility in graphene plasmonic waveguide [10,11] and broadband modulator [12,13], graphene antenna and photodetector [14]. All of these applications have advantages over traditional devices due to their intrinsic tunability and small scale size [15–17]. Within these applications, it is desirable for the devices to have the capability to manipulate the optical properties (light reflection, transmission and absorption) of the plasmonic graphene. Based on the periodic graphene antidot arrays, multi-band plasmonic resonant spectroscopy has been observed [18,19]. Usually, the frequency of a plasmon mode can be artificially manipulated by modifying the graphene's carrier density [20], the structural feature [21], or the surrounding medium [22]. The spectral resonant intensity
can be modified by changing the graphene layers [23]. Based on the periodically asymmetric graphene nanodisk pair, Fano resonanceand plasmon-induced transparency have been observed [24,25,28]. Moreover, plasmonic properties of conventional metallic nano-structures have also been demonstrated to be efficiently tuned by using graphene [26]. While numerous demonstrations of tuning these properties exist in the previous reports, there has been no study on systematically tuning the spectral Q-factor of the graphene plasmonic resonances. Spectral Q-factor is particularly relevant in nonlinear optics [27,28], optical filtering and sensing [29,30]. Although the feasibility for achieving a much broadened spectral bandwidth has been demonstrated via introducing plasmon-plasmon hybridized states in the multiple alternating layer graphene nanoribbons [31–34], the investigation on the narrowband graphene plasmon mode for high-Q resonant spectrum is still unexplored.
In this paper, we present a simple method to manipulate the spectral Q-factor by plasmonic hybridized coupling in a split graphene nanodisks array. In sharp contrast to the previous reports with a series of layered or packed graphene nano-structures in an unit cell for spectral manipulation [31], only an air slit is introduced in this graphene nanodisk to form an asymmetrical graphene resonators dimer. The split graphene nano-disk structure used to accomplish this is designed to
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.optmat.2018.12.052 Received 8 October 2018; Received in revised form 21 December 2018; Accepted 28 December 2018
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: zliu@jxnu.edu.cn, lzhq86025@163.com (Z. Liu).
Optical Materials 89 (2019) 18–24
0925-3467/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
provide different plasmon modes occurred at the close frequency range, where coupling and communication between these modes results in the formation of multiple hybrid resonances with the spectral Q-factor enhancement of approximately 230–360%. We also demonstrate that the high-Q plasmon modes can be scaled in the frequency by tuning the structural parameters. Moreover, polarization-adjusting optical spectrum is also observed for this high-Q graphene plasmonic platform. The classical Malus law for spectral intensity manipulation is confirmed excellently in this split graphene resonant structure.

sections.heading: 2. Design and model
sections.text:
Graphene is considered as an anisotropic material. It is modeled by the surface conductivity σ, which is obtained by the random-phase approximation in the local limit [35,36]. In the lower THz range, the interband contribution for the surface conductivity can be safely neglected owing to the Pauli exclusion principle. Thereby, the surface conductivity σ can be obtained by an approximated Drude model
= +
+ − σ 1 e E πħ j ω jτ 2 f 1 (1)
where e is the electron charge, Ef is the Fermi energy, ħ is the reduced Planck constant, ω is the angular frequency of the illumination light, τ is the relaxation time. Additionally, the relaxation time τ is defined as
=τ μE ev f
f 2
(2)
wherein the relaxation time τ depends on the electron mobility μ (∼10000 cm2V−1s−1), Ef and the Fermi velocity νf∼ 106ms−1. Furthermore, the permittivity εg can be described by the diagonal tensor form [37].
= = + =ε ε jσ
ε ωt ε2.5 , 2.5xx yy g zz 0 (3)
wherein ε0 is the permittivity of vacuum, the tg is the effective thickness as the value of 1 nm. Flexible poly(dimethylsiloxane) film with the εsub of 2.5 is used as the substrate to support the flat graphene nano-disks array. In the initial setup, the Fermi energy of graphene Ef of 0.6 eV is considered. The optical properties of the conventional graphene nanodisks and the split graphene resonator unit cell are simulated using three-dimensional finite-difference time-domain method [38,39]. The nano-disks array is reproduced by using periodic boundary conditions along the x- and y-direction. Perfectly matched layers are utilized in the z direction along the propagation of the incidence plane wave, which are used to completely absorb the scattering optical fields. A minimal mesh size of 0.2 nm is used to refine the calculation. A linear polarization illumination with the electric field along x-direction is used.

sections.heading: 3.1. Optical properties of the graphene nano-disks
sections.text:
Graphene nano-strutures can provide strong optical response to infrared or terahertz electromagnetic waves due to the plasmonic resonances excitation at proper Fermi levels [40]. Before the study on the split graphene nano-disks array, the optical behaviors for the circular graphene resonators are investigated. As shown in Fig. 1(a), the schematic geometry of the graphene nano-disks array is formed by a monolayer graphene nano-disks array on a flexible poly(dimethylsiloxane) film substrate. The structural parameters of the array period (P) and the diameter (D) of the graphene disk are with the stable values of 600 nm and 420 nm until the changes marked in the following discussion. The effective thickness of the graphene is set to be 1 nm. We employ three-dimensional finite-difference time-domain method to simulate the optical properties and the plasmonic resonant behaviors of
the proposed graphene structures. For the proposed graphene disks array, it can be fabricated with the e-beam lithography method [21]. The as-grown graphene can be first transferred onto the substrate, then patterned into closely packed disk arrays using e-beam lithography. Oxygen plasma can then be used to etch away the exposed area, leaving the periodic pattern of graphene disks [21].
Fig. 1(b) shows the obtained optical properties of the conventional graphene circular resonators. As for the graphene nano-disks array, a strong transmission (T) inhibition band is observed at the wavelength of 15.530 μm. Moreover, for the light reflection (R), the spectral intensity is up to 0.55 at 15.555 μm. Light absorption A, is defined as A=1 - T - R, shows a corresponding absorption peak centered at 15.468 μm with A of 0.40. In order to know the mechanism of the strong spectral response, normalized electrical and magnetic field distributions are shown in Fig. 1(b), where the patterns are located in the yoz plane with the position cutting through a disk along y-direction. It is observed that the main electrical field is confined at the rear sides of the graphene disk along the y-direction, which indicates the excitation of dipolar plasmon mode of the graphene disk at this resonant spectral range. The magnetic field is observed to be concentrated in the close area of the disk, which confirms the formation of the resonant plasmon dipole by the graphene disk under certain electromagnetic wave excitation. Similar to the plasmonic dipolar mode in the metallic nanostructures, the spectral bandwidth is usually broad and the corresponding spectral Qfactor is relatively low. Herein, for the graphene disk resonators array, the spectral Q-factor is 15.75, suggesting a broadband optical response.

sections.heading: 3.2. Multispectral high-Q plasmon modes of the split graphene nano-disks
sections.text:
Plasmon modes in graphene have been realized using periodically patterned nano-structures, e.g., one-dimensional nano-ribbons [41] or micro-ribbons [42] and two-dimensional nano-rings/disks [43,44]. Moreover, graphene-insulator film stacking structures have also been proposed and demonstrated to enhance the feasibility for tuning the
plasmonic resonant features [45–47]. Although these designs can provide alternative ways for manipulating plasmonic resonant magnitude and spectral frequency range, they usually suffer a broadband plasmon mode and a relatively low Q-factor. The Q-factor is defined as the ratio of central resonant wavelength to the full width at half maximum. The low-Q plasmon mode behavior of these graphene nano-structures inevitably hampers potential applications on the narrowband filtering and label-free sensing. Recently, dielectric gratings have been used to support optical coupling and diffraction excitation of narrowband plasmon mode, where the Q-factor is close to ∼40 [48] by utilizing the guided-mode resonance of the optical grating. However, the challenges of the proposed process of experimental preparations could remain since the rough gratings may lead to strong and random electromagnetic wave scattering [49], which thus results in bigger losses and lower Q-factors in the practical devices. Moreover, owing to the utilized dielectric gratings, it is difficult to obtain multi-band guided modes, thus leading to a single narrowband plasmon mode in the nano-structured graphene system [50,51]. In contrast to the tradditional graphene plasmon with a relative low Q-factor, spectral Q factor of the plasmonic resonances by the metals has been strongly improved in these years [52–59]. High Q-factor has been obtained in the metallic plasmonic resonant systems due to the Fano resonances [52–56] and hybrid coupling effect [57].
In order to achieve multi-band and high-Q plasmonic responses in graphene, we propose a simple, universal, and feasible design via a split graphene nano-disks array. The schematic geometry of our proposed structure is shown in Fig. 2(a). The split graphene nano-disks are directly located on the dielectric substrate. An air slit is introduced in the graphene disk to form a paired asymmetrical crescents structure. The symmetry breaking is finished by moving the air slit away from the disk center with a displacement value of δ. As for the split graphene nanodisks array, a suitable structural geometry is used to show the optical properties as an example for the design scheme. The structural parameters (D, P, w, δ) are chosen to be 420 nm, 600 nm, 20 nm, 60 nm, respectively. A 500-nm-thick dielectric film with the refractive index of
1.58 is used as the transparent substrate. Under a normal linear polarization illumination with the electric field along y-direction, tri-band transmission spectrum is observed as the labels (λ1-λ3) marked in Fig. 2(b). At λ1= 10.598 μm, optical transmission T is down to 0.518. The spectral full-width at half-maximal is 0.1877 μm and the Q-factor is calculated to be 56.45, suggesting an enhancement of 360% for the spectral Q-factor than that of the conventional graphene nano-disks. At λ2, optical transmission T is down to 0.19 and the spectral Q-factor is 36.10. For the third transmission dip, the Q-factor of the plasmon mode is 39.68. That is, for the split graphene nano-disks array, multiple plasmon modes are obtained, suggesting great difference to that of the single plasmon mode of the conventional graphene resonant structures. At these resonant wavelength ranges, three reflection peaks are observed. The light absorption spectrum is also presented based on the definition of A=1 - T - R, where the T and R represents respectively the transmission and reflection. For the tri-band high absorption spectrum, the minimal A is exceeding 38% (λ1) and the maximal A is up to 49% (λ2). Moreover, some of relatively weak absorption peaks (λ01, λ02) or transmission dips are observed at the shorter wavelength range, which could be the results of the hybrid modes by the graphene surface plasmons and their near-field coupling effects in the periodic array of the split graphene nano-disks [40,60]. These optical features confirm the excitation of multi-band high-Q plasmon modes by the split graphene nano-disks array.
To get the well-understand of the achieved tri-band high-Q spectral response for the split graphene nano-disks array, the normalized electric and magnetic field distributions are shown in Fig. 3. For the first band occurred at λ1, the main electric field is observed in the slit and the rear side of the smaller graphene part. The corresponding magnetic field is mainly confined at the area of the smaller graphene part (Fig. 3(a)) and other field is concentrated at the area close to the slit by the larger graphene part. The electric field distribution Ex in the xoy plane shows remarkable electron oscillations in the surface areas of the two graphene parts, which are located face-to-face. The electric field distribution Ey shows noticeable resonant field at the rear sides of the air slit. These field distributions suggest that the excitation of the plasmon dipolar-like mode of the smaller graphene part and the partial dipolar-like mode by the larger graphene part at the area close to the air slit is the main contribution for the resonance in this frequency region. At λ2, electric field is observed to be confined at the rear sides of the larger graphene part as shown in Fig. 3(b). The magnetic field mainly concentrated in the close area of the larger graphene part confirms the excitation of the plasmonic dipole resonance. Moreover, partial magnetic field is also observed in the proximity area to the slit supported by the smaller graphene resonator. The Ex distribution in the xoy plane shows a strong electric field existed at the left area for the larger graphene part, which confirms the excitation of the plasmonic dipole resonance. Moreover, as the Ey distribution shown in the xoy plane, the main field is observed in the left large part of the split graphene disk. These features confirm that the observed resonant response in this wavelength range mainly results from the plasmon dipolar-like mode by the larger graphene part. Fig. 3(c) shows the optical field response for the third band. The electric field in the top row is observed to be distributed in the slit and the side areas of the graphene disk along the polarization direction (y-axis). The magnetic field is divided into two parts, which are separately located on the areas close to the left and the right parts of the split graphene disk. Moreover, these strong magnetic fields are observed to be spatially coupled and interacted for the two split parts. The bottom distribution pattern shows the paired negative and positive electric field distributions on either side of the air slit, which confirms the plasmonic coupling between these split graphene nano-disks. The Ey distribution pattern also shows that the strong electric fields are confined in the air slit. Other fields are observed to be distributed in the whole disk area. These features verify the strong hybrid coupling by the adjacent graphene plasmon parts, which produces a similar dipolar resonance by the circular graphene disk.
Furthermore, Fig. 3(d) and (e) show the resonant field distributions for the sub-peaks observed in the spectrum. At λ01, the top two rows with the E and H field distributions in the yoz planes both show that the fields are mainly observed in the area close to the smaller part and the air slit. The electric field Ex and Ey distribution patterns in the xoy planes directly show two main features. One the two pairs of negative and positive fields in the smaller graphene part. The other is the additional two pairs of the negative and positive fields distributed in the surface area of the air slit close to the large part. These features indicate the excitation of high-order plasmon resonance by the split graphene disk [40,60–62]. At λ02, the field distributions of E and H clearly show that the main fields are confined at the area close to the smaller graphene part. The electric field distribution Ex in the xoy plane confirm the strong field in the smaller part. These features suggest that the plasmon resonance by the smaller part is the main contribution for this sub-peak. Thus, by introducing a spatial slit into the graphene disk, strongly and spatially selective resonant coupling effects and hybrid modes are obtained for the complementary graphene resonators. These behaviors directly lead to the observed spectral hybridization and highQ plasmon modes.
Optical properties of the split graphene nano-disks array are further investigated by tuning the Fermi energy. The surface conductivity of graphene relates strongly to the Femi energy. The Fermi energy can be highly controlled by electrostatic and chemical doping. For instance, electrically active tuning of the graphene plasmons has been investigated for the optoelectronic devices via additional electric manipulation on the graphene [12–14,17,21]. Conducting cover layer with optical transparency or other transparent conductors are used during the formation of the device [21]. These features indicate a feasible way to tune the properties of the graphene plasmonics. As shown in Fig. 4, with increasing Ef from 0.4 eV to 0.8, 1.0 and 1.2 eV, three main characteristics can be observed. One is the tri-band spectrum, which can be maintained for the system under different Ef. Otherwise, noticeable spectral blue-shift for the triple bands can be observed during the increase of Ef. Another feature is the spectrally narrowing for the triband spectrum. Under the situation with a Ef of 1.2 eV, the Q-factor is up to 64.03 for the first transmission dip, suggesting an enhancement of 407% in comparison with that of the circular graphene disk. These features also suggest a way to further improve the spectral Q-factor for the multi-band resonant modes by using a relatively larger Ef.
Additionally, the transmission (reflection) spectra with a few sub-dips (sub-peaks) at the shorter wavelength range can be observed. Based on the previous reports [18,19], periodic graphene antidot arrays can support multiple surface plasmon resonances due to the different diffraction orders. As for the periodic graphene disk arrays in this work, the weak resonant modes occurred at the shorter wavelength range mainly result from the lattice diffractive resonances.

sections.heading: 3.3. Tunable plasmon modes of the split graphene nano-disks via structural parameters
sections.text:
Fig. 5 presents the transmission properties for the split graphene nano-disks under different structural parameters. As shown in Fig. 5(a), light transmission shows different responses for the tri-band spectra when the air slit (w=20 nm) is located at different positions. With increasing δ from 20 nm to 80 nm, the plasmon mode at λ1 shows a continuous spectral blue-shift. The spectral transmission inhibition also becomes weaker and weaker. These features are the main results of the spectral blue-shift of the smaller graphene part since the plamon dipole mode and its resonant frequency is greatly relevant to the resonator size. Moreover, the hybridized coupling can be weakened for the extremely asymmetry system. For the mode at λ2, with increasing δ, transmission dip shows a noticeable red-shift at the wavelength range. The spectral intensity also presents a slight fluctuation. At λ3, a remarkable spectral blue-shift is observed. Moreover, the transmission depth is also deeper and deeper with increasing δ. For instance, with changing δ from 20 nm to 80 nm, the transmission dips (λ2 and λ3) show spectral shifts (transmission changes) from 11.647 μm (T=0.219) and 13.859 μm (T=0.548) to 12.644 μm (T=0.247) and 13.642 μm (T=0.258). These features not only confirm the plasmon near-field coupling and hybridization effect between the adjacent graphene resonators but also verify the feasible way for tuning the optical properties by the slit positions. In contrast to the distinct optical responses of the multi-band spectrum for the split graphene nano-disks by tuning the slit position, a similar spectral shift behavior is obtained for the platform when the diameter of the disk is manipulated. As shown in Fig. 5(b), with increasing D from 400 nm to 460 nm, the tri-band spectral curve shows an unitary red-shift at the wavelength range. Moreover, the narrow bandwidths and high-Q factors for these transmission dips are retained during the manipulation
process. These features confirm the feasible adjusting for the high-Q plasmon modes to occur at desirable wavelength range by artificially design of the structural size.

sections.heading: 3.4. Quantitative manipulation of high-Q plasmon modes via exterior parameters
sections.text:
Additionally, artificially control and quantitative manipulation of these high-Q plasmon modes are investigated to promote this simple functional graphene platform for applications in optoelectronics. Fig. 6(a) shows the optical properties of the split graphene nano-disks array with the air slit of w=40 nm and δ=60 nm. It is observed that all the three-band light transmission, reflection and absorption show a sharp and narrow spectral lineshape. For instance, the spectral Q-factor for the tri-band transmission is up to 53.55, 49.62 and 40.33 for the dips at λ1-λ3, respectively. These values suggest an enhancement of Qfactor from ∼256% to 340% for the multi-band plasmon modes. Moreover, the absorption peaks at λ1-λ3 show high efficiency absorption at these resonant wavelengths by the split graphene nano-disks array. The corresponding A for the absorption peaks at λ1-λ3are up to 43.6%, 45.1% and 46.0%, respectively.
Although there are many reports on manipulating plasmonic response of the graphene nano-structures via the structural parameters or its tunable Fermi level, far less attention is paid for the feasibility for achieving artificial manipulation of optical properties by exterior techniques. Here, based on the split graphene nano-disks array, we do further study on the quantitative manipulation of the multi-band highQ plasmon modes by controlling the polarization states of the illumination. As depicted in Fig. 6(b), the absorption spectral curves show regular changes when the polarization angle φ changed from 0° to 90° with an interval of 10°. For the original absorption peaks at λ1-λ3, the intensity shows a continuous decrease during the polarization manipulation process. Additionally, an absorption peak at λ4emerges and becomes stronger and stronger in this process. The emerged peak is the main results of the excitation of the plasmon mode by the split graphene resonator due to the electric field parallelingto the slit. In order to get
the quantitative response for the polarization-adjusting management, the spectral absorption intensity of the plasmon modes (λ2 and λ4) at the corresponding polarization angle φis plotted in Fig. 6(c) and (d), respectively. Moreover, the ideal results of the classical Malus law are also plotted to give direct comparison. It is observed that the results are very close to or equal to the ideal data of the Malus law, indicating the feasibility for quantitative manipulation of the high-Q multispectral plasmon modes by adjusting the exterior polarization states. The slight offset for the case at λ2 mainly results from the strong plasmon nearfield effect of the hybridized coupling for the split graphene nano-disks.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, we investigate the high-Q multispectral plasmon modes of the graphene nano-structures and show artificially quantitative manipulation on the optical properties via exterior technique in detail. It is found that the split graphene nano-disks array produces multiple dipolar resonances and the corresponding plasmon near-field coupling effects, making the spectral Q-factor with an enhancement of ∼360% than that of the original graphene disk. Optical properties of the split graphene nano-disks array are investigated by tuning the Fermi energy. With increasing Ef, the tri-band spectrum can not only retain but also shows a narrowing behavior for the resonant bandwidth, which eventually leads to an enhancement ∼400% for the spectral Q-factor in comparison with that of the circular graphene disk. Moreover, the observed multi-band high-Q plamson modes can be controlled via the polarization states of the illumination. Classical Malus law is confirmed in this high-Q optical system, indicating alternative way to quantitatively manipulate the graphene plasmons. These results demonstrate the great potential of using split graphene disks based platform for multi-band, high-Q, tunable absorption, filtering and sensing.
Conflict of interest
The authors declare no conflict of interest.

Recently, dielectric gratings have been used to support optical coupling and diffraction excitation of narrowband plasmon mode, where the Q-factor is close to ∼40 [48] by utilizing the guided-mode resonance of the optical grating.

However, the challenges of the proposed process of experimental preparations could remain since the rough gratings may lead to strong and random electromagnetic wave scattering [49], which thus results in bigger losses and lower Q-factors in the practical devices.

Moreover, owing to the utilized dielectric gratings, it is difficult to obtain multi-band guided modes, thus leading to a single narrowband plasmon mode in the nano-structured graphene system [50,51].

metadata.abstractText: We propose a new approach to directly tune spectral Q-factor of the graphene, which has remained challenging in these years. The remarkable tuning of optical properties is reported by splitting graphene disk resonators. In contrast to the single mode of the circular graphene disk, the split graphene nano-disks produce new emerged plasmonic resonant modes, which can be further modified by tuning structural parameters. Such split graphene nano-disks can not only strengthen the multispectral light-graphene interactions drastically but also improve the spectral Q-factor naturally. The spectral Q-factor shows an enhancement of 230–360% for the proposed split graphene nano-disks in comparison with that of the conventional graphene plasmonic mode. With increasing Fermi energy, the tri-band spectrum shows a further narrowing behavior for the resonant bandwidth. A maximal enhancement ∼400% for the spectral Q-factor is obtained. Moreover, the graphene plasmonic properties can be artificially modulated by polarization states of the illumination. This study will open up an avenue for effectively operating graphene photonic devices in the infrared range and pave a way for high-Q multispectral plasmonic graphene structures.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
